indicators.justification:
The U.S. passed the Endangered Species Act (ESA) in 1973, to protect and recover imperiled species and the ecosystems upon which they depend. It is administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (Service) and the Commerce Department's National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). (1) The Environmental Conservation Online System provides open data on endangered U.S. Species by Taxonomic Group. (2) A species can be listed under the ESA two different ways: through the petition process or through the candidate assessment process. The ESA provides that any interested person may petition the Secretary of the Interior to add a species to, or to remove a species from, the list of endangered and threatened species. Through the candidate assessment process, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service biologists identify species as listing candidates. (3) 

Sources:
1. Endangered Species Act, https://www.fws.gov/endangered/laws-policies/index.html
2. Endangered Species Data, https://ecos.fws.gov/ecp/report/species-listings-by-tax-group-totals
3. Endangered Species Program Process, https://www.fws.gov/endangered/about/faq.html

indicators.justification:
The United States recently passed the Corporate Transparency Act (CTA), enacted into law as part of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021 (NDAA) requiring that beneficial ownership data be made available, but it has not been implemented yet. Specifically, Section 6403 of the Corporate Transparency Act requires reporting companies (corporations, limited liability companies (LLCs), and similar entities, subject to certain statutory exemptions) to submit to the Treasury Department's FinCEN agency specified information on their beneficial owners—the individual natural persons who own or control them—as well as specified information about the persons who form or register those reporting companies. (1) The law requires the reporting requirements must be promulgated by January 1, 2022, with an effective date to be determined thereafter. (2)

Historically, companies were required to identify a "responsible party" to the IRS tax administration when applying for an Employer Identification Number (EIN) which tracks closely to "beneficial owner" definitions, but this information was only available to law enforcement for use in tax investigations with a court order.(3)

At the local level, the state of Washington is the best subnational example of sharing corporate data as assessed by Open Corporates. (4) 

Sources: 
1. Draft Beneficial Ownership Data Requirements, https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2021/04/05/2021-06922/beneficial-ownership-information-reporting-requirements 
2. Corporate Transparency Act, https://www.congress.gov/116/bills/hr6395/BILLS-116hr6395enr.pdf 
3. G-20 Anti-Corruption Working Group, https://star.worldbank.org/sites/star/files/g20_bo_country_guide_united_states.pdf
4. Open Corporates - Washington, https://opencorporates.com/registers/279

evidence.title: Corporate Transparency Act is Title LXIV of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Public Law 116-283

indicators.justification:
The National Vital Statistics System (NVSS) provides the most complete data on births and deaths in the United States. The National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) is the federal agency legislatively mandated to produce national health statistics based on this cooperative, decentralized system in which data from more than 6 million vital-event records are collected each year by all states and U.S. territories and transmitted to NCHS for processing and dissemination. This national dataset provides models to states for standard inputs. (3) Updates on new data releases are provided on the NVSS news feed. (4)

Sources: 
1. National Vital Statistics System (NVSS), https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/index.htm
2. The U.S. Vital Statistics System: A National Perspective Book, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK219884
3. NVSS State Models, https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/products/misc_pubs.htm#modelstate
4. NVSS Data News, https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/new_nvss.htm

indicators.justification:
In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services began aggregating national hospitalization data in 2020. The data are derived from reports by each facility within the last four days with facility-level granularity across two main sources: HHS TeleTracking, and reporting provided directly to HHS Protect by state/territorial health departments on behalf of their healthcare facilities. No statistical analysis is applied to account for non-response and/or to account for missing data. The data is provided as an interactive dashboard and as open data. (1) (2)

Sources:
1. HHS Protect Public Data Hub, https://protect-public.hhs.gov/pages/hospital-utilization
2. COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility Data, https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/anag-cw7u

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services began aggregating national vaccination data in 2021. It is a daily snapshot in time that focuses on recent COVID-19 outcomes in the last seven days and changes relative to the week prior. Data in this report may differ from data on state and local websites. This may be due to differences in how data were reported (e.g., date specimen obtained, or date reported for cases) or how the metrics are calculated. indicators.justification:
There is limited consistent national data for land use in the United States, but instead various local government information, much of it not available as open data. In 2013, the Sunlight Foundation did a landscape study of local zoning data. (1) 

For national data, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service conducts a Major Land Uses (MLU) series, which is the most comprehensive accounting of all major uses of public and private land in the United States. (2) The series was started in 1945, and has since been published about every 5 years, coinciding with the Census of Agriculture. The last series was conducted in 2012 with estimates, that with few exceptions were constructed from available data rather than used exactly as developed by source agencies. These datasets vary greatly in scope, methods, definitions, and other characteristics. To explore more one can read the documentation for those datasets. The available data contain conflicts and overlaps that must be reconciled or removed.(3) 

Protected land data is provided in another dataset, the USGS Protected Areas Database of the United States (PAD-US) is the nation's inventory of protected areas, including public land and voluntarily provided private protected areas. (4)

Sources: 
1. Sunlight Foundation - Landscape of Local Open Zoning Data, 2013, https://sunlightfoundation.com/policy/municipal_zoning/
2. ERS Major Land Use Series, 2012, https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/major-land-uses.aspx
3. ERS Major Land Use Series Documentation, https://www.ers.usda.gov/webdocs/publications/84880/eib-178.pdf?v=9510.3)
4. USGS Protected Land Data, https://data.doi.gov/dataset/protected-areas-database-of-the-united-states-pad-us

indicators.justification:
The United States provides structured data for many stages of the budget process (including individual agency budget justifications, the President's whole federal proposed budget, and Congress' projected budget and actual appropriated funds), and provides agency spending data as open data. (1) (2) (3) (4) In 2021, a new law was passed that requires agencies to provide their budget justifications as open data in a centrally located website. Previously, this information was not structured nor centralized. The DATA Act requires agencies to submit open spending data to the Treasury Department in standard formats that support quality and to some extent international standards. USASpending provides an API, bulk data access, and data visualizations on key topics. Recently, because of the CARES Act legislation, all spending for COVID-19 data was tracked and provided on USASpending. (5) 

While the United States continues to make progress with the availability of their budget and spending data, GAO and agency inspectors general highlight that many agencies continue to fail to report required spending data, or report it with errors. (6) (7) There is great opportunity to build out the standard spending data 'object class' field to provide more transparency on government performance. While there is much public information, specific amendments to budgets or inconsistent spending is not structured and would take some research to assess. Unreported spending data is calculated using the difference in the total obligated amount from the Report on Budget Execution and Budgetary Resources (excluding financing accounts) and the total obligated amount reported by agencies to USAspending.gov in 'Account Breakdown by Program Activity & Object Class' data (also called 'File B' data, see the DAIMS data standards for more information). (8) 

1. Agency Congressional Budget Justification example, https://gsa.gov/cj
2. President's Budget Data, https://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/budget/
3. Congressional Budget Office Data, https://www.cbo.gov/data/budget-economic-data#9
4. Congressional Appropriated Budget Information, https://www.congress.gov/help/appropriations-and-budget
5. USASpending.gov (Reported Spending Data and Explorer), https://usaspending.gov
6. Various GAO reports on the DATA Act, https://www.gao.gov/blog/subject_terms/10866
7. DATA Act Metadata Standard, https://www.fiscal.treasury.gov/data-transparency/DAIMS-v2.1.html

indicators.justification:
In the United States, the Lobbying Disclosure Act requires the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives to make all registrations and reports available for public inspection over the Internet as soon as technically practicable after the report is filed. Congress' two branches, the Senate and the House of Representatives provide this information in two separate lobbyist databases that are searchable and sortable, and provide downloadable PDF reports. indicators.justification:
The United States recently passed the Corporate Transparency Act (CTA), enacted into law as part of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021 (NDAA) requiring that beneficial ownership data be made available, but it has not been implemented yet. (1) Specifically, Section 6403 of the Corporate Transparency Act requires reporting companies (corporations, limited liability companies (LLCs), and similar entities, subject to certain statutory exemptions) to submit to the Treasury Department's FinCEN agency specified information on their beneficial owners—the individual natural persons who own or control them—as well as specified information about the persons who form or register those reporting companies. The law requires the reporting requirements must be promulgated by January 1, 2022, with an effective date to be determined thereafter. While the definition of "reporting company" is broad, there are a whole host of exceptions to the definition. Such exceptions include, but are not limited to, public companies; non-foreign-owned shell companies; financial institutions (such as banks, credit unions, brokers, dealers, and exchange and clearing agencies); investment companies; insurance companies operating within the United States; public utility companies; accounting firms; pooled investment vehicles; nonprofit and political organizations; and entities that employ more than 20 employees, filed federal tax returns demonstrating more than $5 million in gross receipts or sales, and have an operating presence within the United States. (2) The CTA defines the "beneficial owner" of an entity, subject to certain exceptions, as "an individual who, directly or indirectly, through any contract, arrangement, understanding, relationship, or otherwise" either "exercises substantial control over the entity" or "owns or controls not less than 25 percent of the ownership Start Printed Page 17562interests of the entity." (3) (4) FinCEN has begun creating rules for the reporting requirements and data standards including identifiers.

Sources:
1. Pub. L. 116–92, https://www.congress.gov/116/plaws/publ93/PLAW-116publ93.pdf
2. Corporate Transparency Act: What Companies Need to Know, https://corpgov.law.harvard.edu/2021/02/18/corporate-transparency-act-what-companies-need-to-know/
3. Beneficial Ownership Information Reporting Requirements, https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2021/04/05/2021-06922/beneficial-ownership-information-reporting-requirements
4. 17 CFR § 240.13d-3, https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/17/240.13d-3

indicators.justification:
The Federal Evidence-based Policymaking Act requires all public datasets must be posted in machine-readable formats. (1) Further, Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act and Section 255 of the Communications Act requires access to electronic and information technology provided by the Federal government. (2) The law applies to all Federal agencies when they develop, procure, maintain, or use electronic and information technology. Federal agencies must ensure that this technology is accessible to employees and members of the public with disabilities to the extent it does not pose an "undue burden." Section 508 speaks to various means for disseminating information, including computers, software, and electronic office equipment.  The definition of electronic and information technology in Section 508 means "any equipment or interconnected system or subsystem of equipment, that is used in the automatic acquisition, storage, manipulation, management, movement, control, display, switching, interchange, transmission, or reception of data or information. It includes computer hardware, software, networks, and peripherals as well as many electronic and communications devices commonly used in offices." (3)  While Section 508 applies to federal agencies, state law is similar. (4)

Sources:
1. Public Law 115-435, https://www.congress.gov/115/plaws/publ435/PLAW-115publ435.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. § 552a, outlines a broad framework for privacy for Federal datasets only. (1) The Privacy Act prohibits the disclosure of a record about an individual from a system of records absent the written consent of the individual, unless the disclosure is pursuant to one of twelve statutory exceptions. The Act also provides individuals with a means by which to seek access to and amendment of their records, and sets forth various agency record-keeping requirements. In addition to the Privacy Act, there is a range of data protection regulations for specific datasets collected by the Federal Government which can be observed in the Federal Privacy Council's Law Library. (2) For example, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) regulates personal health information and sets limits and conditions on the uses and disclosures. In reaction to the COVID-19 Pandemic, the Federal Government waived all provisions of the HIPAA privacy, security, and breach notification rules if a telehealth provider acted in good faith compliance with the guidance. Lastly, there is a range of state data protection regulations covering consumer data, biometrics, and more. (3) (4) (5)

indicators.justification:
On January 14, 2019 the Foundations for Evidence-based Policymaking Act was signed into law. Title II of the Foundations for Evidence-based Policymaking is entitled the Open Government Data Act and requires Federal agencies to provide all public data assets as "open government data" and under an "open license" as defined by law and in line with guidance by the Office of Management and Budget. (1) This law greatly resembles similar executive policies and codifies it with a few notable additions including defining public data assets as anything that would be made available under a Freedom of Information Act public records request and new requirements for Chief Data Officers and open data plans. The Open Government Data Act includes "open standards" as part of the definition of "open government data" but does not prescribe within the law particular standards to adhere to. The Office of Management and Budget has provided partial guidance on implementing this law with M-19-23 (2) and guidance on Resources.data.gov (3), including a standards catalog, but as noted by the Government Accountability Office is tardy on further guidance on how to implement this law. (4) It should be noted many states and cities in the U.S. also have their own open data laws.(5)

L. 93–344, title II, § 203, July 12, 1974) required the Congressional Budget Office to provide public access to budget data. (2) The Congressional Budget Justification Transparency Act was signed into law on September 30, 2021 including a requirement for agencies to post Congressional Budget Justifications to be posted online in a standard format.(3)

indicators.justification:
In the United States, there are federal campaign finance regulations and various local campaign finance regulations. The first federal campaign finance law, the Tillman Act, was enacted in 1907. In the years following the enactment of that law, campaign finance has remained a source of contention in American politics. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002, and a series of federal court cases, including Buckley v. Valeo and Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, together form the foundation of federal campaign finance law. Campaign finance laws require disclosure of income and spending of candidates and their committee affiliates and disclosure of individual donor information. (1)

Campaign finance e-filing is required by law (§ 104.18 Electronic filing of reports (52 U.S.C. 30102(d) and 30104(a)(11))) for committees if they receive contributions or make expenditures in excess of $50,000 in the current calendar year, or have reason to expect to do so and encourages voluntary electronic filers. (2) When this data is electronically filed it is run through a validator to ensure standard open data. (3) The FEC website reiterates the legal definitions of clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties. (4) The FEC Website provides an API, searchable database, and bulk open data. (5)

Sources:

1. Ballotpedia - US Campaign Finance Laws, https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_campaign_finance_laws_and_regulations
2. FEC - Regulations, https://www.fec.gov/regulations/104-18/2021-annual-104#104-18
3. FEC - e-filing instructions, https://www.fec.gov/help-candidates-and-committees/filing-reports/electronic-filing/
4. FEC website, https://fec.gov

indicators.justification:
The Freedom of Information Act (states that any person "has the right to request access to federal agency records or information except to the extent the records are protected from disclosure by any of nine exemptions contained in the law or by one of three special law enforcement record exclusions." The FOIA has been amended several times to include more electronic reporting requirements. (1) In 1996, Congress enacted the Electronic Freedom of Information Act Amendments of 1996, which addressed the subject of electronic records, as well as proactive disclosures and agency backlogs of FOIA requests, among other procedural provisions. The most recent amendments to the FOIA were made by the FOIA Improvement Act of 2016. The 2016 amendments addressed proactive disclosures, requiring agencies to make available "for public inspection in an electronic format," records "that have been requested 3 or more times." The 2016 amendments revised the duties of the Office of Government Information Services and created new reporting obligations for that office. In addition, the amendments addressed the reporting obligations of the Department of Justice, added two elements to agency Annual FOIA Reports, and directed agencies to review their FOIA regulations.(2)

Sources:
1. Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, https://www.justice.gov/oip/freedom-information-act-5-usc-552
2. Department of Justice History of FOIA, https://www.justice.gov/oip/page/file/1248371/download#page=6

The U.S. government uses federal procurement data by incorporating it into USASpending.gov for a more complete picture of how federal money is spent. (1) Media outlets like ProPublica have created dashboards to track procurement contracts related to COVID-19 (2), and The Washington Post has used procurement data to fact-check political claims about spending.(3) 

Sources:
1. USASpending.gov Data Sources include Procurement Data, https://www.usaspending.gov/about
2. Propublica Covid Contract Dashboard, https://projects.propublica.org/coronavirus-contracts/
3. Washington Post Contract Analysis, https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/01/27/bidens-jab-that-foreign-company-contracts-went-up-30-under-trump/
